data.title: 14 Best Art Galleries and Museums in Manchester
data.meta_description: Explore Manchester's best art galleries and museums, from the iconic Manchester Art Gallery to the innovative exhibitions at The Whitworth
data.text:
Manchester is known for its rich history and vibrant art scene. The city’s art galleries and museums showcase diverse collections, including classical and modern art, as well as significant scientific and social history exhibitions. Whether you are interested in the captivating works of the Pre-Raphaelites, the groundbreaking exhibits of contemporary artists, or the fascinating narratives of Manchester’s industrial and social evolution, the city’s institutions provide a compelling journey through time and creativity. Visiting Manchester’s art galleries and museums offers an opportunity to explore world-class collections and immerse oneself in the dynamic spirit of a city that continuously shapes and celebrates the arts. If you plan a trip with our europe tour packages, be rest assured that all the top art galleries and museums will be covered along with other famous places to see in Manchester. Grab the best of deals now to fly to your dream destination!

Best Art Galleries and Museums in Manchester

1. The Whitworth

Overview: The Whitworth is one of the best art galleries and museums in Manchester. It is nestled in Whitworth Park, and is celebrated for its expansive collection of modern and contemporary art, textiles, and wallpapers. Originally founded in 1889, the gallery underwent a major renovation and extension in 2015 by MUMA architects, enhancing its status as a cultural landmark in Manchester.

Highlights: The Whitworth boasts a diverse collection ranging from works by masters like William Blake and J.M.W. Turner to contemporary artists such as Cornelia Parker. Its scenic park setting integrates art with nature, offering visitors a tranquil escape with a sculpture garden and regular community engagements.

Special Exhibitions: The gallery frequently hosts temporary exhibitions that explore various themes and artistic movements. These exhibitions often include interactive installations and multimedia displays, enriching the visitor experience.

Visitor Experience: Visitors can enjoy guided tours, workshops, and educational programs tailored to different age groups. The café overlooking the park is a popular spot, offering a relaxing environment to reflect on the art and surroundings.

2. Manchester Art Gallery

Overview: Located in the heart of Manchester, the Manchester Art Gallery houses an extensive collection of fine art spanning several centuries. Founded in 1824, the gallery showcases Pre-Raphaelite paintings, contemporary art, and decorative arts from around the world. It is renowned to be one of the best art galleries and museums in Manchester.

Highlights: The collection includes works by local artists such as L.S. Lowry and Adolphe Valette, alongside international artists like Van Gogh and Renoir. The gallery’s Victorian architecture and spacious galleries provide an elegant backdrop for its diverse exhibitions.

Special Exhibitions: Manchester Art Gallery regularly hosts temporary exhibitions that delve into specific artists, movements, or thematic explorations. These exhibitions often feature loans from other prestigious collections worldwide.

Visitor Experience: The gallery offers guided tours, talks, and workshops for both adults and children, making it a popular destination for families and art enthusiasts alike. The café and shop provide additional amenities for visitors to relax and browse. Visiting this museum is one of the best things to do in Manchester Europe.

3. The Lowry

Overview: Named after the renowned painter L.S. Lowry, The Lowry is a prominent arts centre located at Salford Quays. Opened in 2000, it combines visual art exhibitions with performing arts venues, including theatres and event spaces.

Highlights: The Lowry’s collection includes a significant number of Lowry’s iconic industrial landscapes, complemented by rotating exhibitions of contemporary art. The building itself, designed by Michael Wilford, is a modern architectural landmark in the area.

Special Exhibitions: In addition to its permanent collection, The Lowry hosts temporary exhibitions that showcase a diverse range of artistic practices, from photography and sculpture to multimedia installations.

Visitor Experience: Visitors can enjoy live performances, workshops, and talks alongside exploring the galleries. The arts centre’s location at Salford Quays offers stunning views of the waterfront and easy access to other cultural attractions. Be sure to visit Lowry – one of the best art galleries and museums in Manchester.

4. Museum of Science and Industry (MSI)

Overview: Housed in the historic buildings of the former Liverpool Road Station, the Museum of Science and Industry (MSI) explores Manchester’s industrial heritage and scientific achievements.

Highlights: Exhibits include working steam engines, vintage aircraft, and interactive displays that trace the city’s role in the Industrial Revolution. The museum’s location within a preserved railway station adds to its historical appeal.

Special Exhibitions: MSI regularly hosts temporary exhibitions that explore contemporary scientific advancements, technological innovations, and their impact on society.

Visitor Experience: The museum offers hands-on activities, demonstrations, and educational workshops suitable for all ages. Its outdoor spaces include a picnic area and a miniature railway, providing additional attractions for families. It’s one of the best museums in Manchester.

Suggested Read: Top 15 Hotels & Resorts in Manchester: Luxury Gateways!

5. People’s History Museum

Overview: Situated in Manchester city centre, the People’s History Museum is dedicated to exploring the history of democracy, social justice, and the fight for equality in Britain.

Highlights: It being one of the best museums in Manchester has a collection of artefacts, artworks, and archives that document key moments in the suffragette movement, labour rights campaigns, and other social movements. Exhibitions often highlight Manchester’s role in these historical events.

Special Exhibitions: Temporary exhibitions at the People’s History Museum focus on contemporary issues and celebrate the contributions of ordinary people to social change. Interactive displays engage visitors in exploring the museum’s themes.

Visitor Experience: The museum offers guided tours, talks, and family-friendly activities that encourage visitors to reflect on the significance of social movements past and present. The café and shop provide opportunities for relaxation and further exploration.

6. The John Rylands Library

Overview: A masterpiece of neo-Gothic architecture, The John Rylands Library is located on Deansgate and houses one of the finest collections of rare books, manuscripts, and archives in the world.

Highlights: The library’s collection includes medieval illuminated manuscripts, early printed books such as the Gutenberg Bible, and literary archives of notable figures. The building itself is renowned for its architectural beauty and historical significance.

Special Exhibitions: The John Rylands Library hosts temporary exhibitions that showcase highlights from its collection, often focusing on specific themes or historical periods. These exhibitions provide insights into the library’s treasures.

Visitor Experience: Visitors can explore the library’s reading rooms, attend guided tours, and participate in special events such as lectures and book signings. The café offers a peaceful setting for visitors to enjoy refreshments.

7. Manchester Museum

Overview: Part of the University of Manchester, Manchester Museum features collections of natural history, archaeology, and anthropology from around the world. It’s one of the top art museums in Manchester.

Highlights: Exhibits include ancient Egyptian artefacts, dinosaur skeletons, and cultural objects that span continents and civilizations. The museum’s galleries offer insights into biodiversity, human evolution, and global cultures.

Special Exhibitions: Manchester Museum hosts temporary exhibitions that explore current research in archaeology, anthropology, and environmental science. These exhibitions often feature collaborations with academic departments.

Visitor Experience: The museum provides interactive displays, family-friendly activities, and educational workshops that cater to diverse interests and age groups. The museum’s café and gift shop enhance the visitor experience.

Suggested Read: 13 Top Places to Visit in Paris On Honeymoon For Newlyweds

8. The Pankhurst Centre

Overview: Located in Emmeline Pankhurst’s former home, The Pankhurst Centre is a museum and women’s centre dedicated to the history of the suffragette movement in Manchester.

Highlights: The centre’s exhibits include artefacts, photographs, and documents that chronicle the suffragette campaign for women’s voting rights. Guided tours offer insights into the lives of the Pankhurst family and their activism.

Special Exhibitions: The Pankhurst Centre hosts temporary exhibitions that explore themes related to women’s rights, social justice, and contemporary feminist movements. These exhibitions engage visitors in ongoing debates.

Visitor Experience: Visitors can participate in guided tours, talks, and workshops that highlight the significance of the suffragette movement. The centre’s location in a historic building adds to its educational and cultural appeal.

9. The Manchester Museum of Art

Overview: A contemporary art gallery situated in the vibrant Northern Quarter, The Manchester Museum of Art showcases local and international artists across various mediums. It is popular as one of the best art galleries and museums in Manchester.

Highlights: The museum’s exhibitions feature innovative contemporary art practices, including painting, sculpture, photography, and multimedia installations. It serves as a platform for emerging and established artists alike.

Special Exhibitions: Temporary exhibitions at The Manchester Museum of Art highlight specific artists, thematic concerns, or experimental art forms. These exhibitions often challenge conventional perspectives on contemporary art.

Visitor Experience: The museum offers a dynamic environment for visitors to engage with contemporary art through guided tours, artist talks, and public programs. The café and gallery shop provide additional amenities for visitors to enjoy.

10. Castlefield Gallery

Overview: Castlefield Gallery is a leading contemporary art gallery located in Manchester’s creative hub, Castlefield. It supports artists at different stages of their careers and promotes experimental art practices.

Highlights: Exhibitions at Castlefield Gallery explore current social, political, and cultural issues through diverse artistic mediums. The gallery’s programming reflects Manchester’s dynamic art scene and its global connections.

Special Exhibitions: Castlefield Gallery hosts temporary exhibitions that feature solo and group shows by local, national, and international artists. These exhibitions often include collaborations with other cultural organisations.

Visitor Experience: Visitors can attend exhibition openings, artist-led tours, and public talks that provide insights into contemporary art practices. The gallery’s location near Manchester’s canals offers scenic views and easy access to other cultural attractions. This makes it one of the best art galleries and museums in Manchester.

Overview: In the heart of Manchester’s city centre, you’ll find the National Football Museum Manchester in the iconic Urbis building. This museum, which opened in 2012, celebrates the history and global influence of football. It offers an engaging experience with historical artefacts, interactive exhibits, and interesting stories. Being one of the best museums in Manchester it’s a must-visit for football fans and anyone interested in culture.

Highlights: The museum features prestigious awards such as the FIFA World Cup and the FA Cup, iconic jerseys worn by legendary players, and a vast archive of photographs and documents capturing football’s development.

Special Exhibitions: The museum often has temporary shows that explore different parts of football culture and history. Recent displays have looked at things like how football affects fashion, the role of women in the sport, and how football influences global politics. These shows usually have videos, things you can interact with, and rare objects that give new ways of looking at the game.

Visitor Experience: The National Football Museum is designed to be easy to navigate and enjoyable. You’ll find clear signs and accessible exhibits throughout the museum. The café offers a comfortable space to relax and enjoy some refreshments with a view of the lively city centre. Additionally, the museum shop has a wide variety of football-themed items, including books, DVDs, replica kits, and souvenirs.

Suggested Read: 12 Places to Visit in London in one Day: Top Must-see Attractions

12. ESEA Contemporary

Overview: ESEA Contemporary, formerly known as the Centre for Chinese Contemporary Art (CFCCA), is a top art institution in Manchester. It focuses on displaying modern art from East and Southeast Asia. The gallery, located in the Northern Quarter, plays a crucial role in promoting understanding and artistic exchange between East Asia, Southeast Asia, and the UK. It has made significant changes to better represent its varied programming and expanded geographical focus.

Highlights: ESEA Contemporary doesn’t have a permanent collection. Instead, it regularly presents temporary exhibitions featuring works by emerging and established artists from East and Southeast Asia. The exhibitions showcase a variety of art forms including painting, sculpture, photography, video, and installation art.

Special Exhibitions: ESEA Contemporary is well-known for its thought-provoking and innovative temporary exhibitions. These exhibitions often deal with important social, political, and cultural issues. They are designed to encourage conversation and offer insight into the diverse experiences and perspectives of artists from East and Southeast Asia.

Visitor Experience: Visitors to ESEA Contemporary can expect an immersive experience with smooth navigation, informative signage, and a vibrant atmosphere in the Northern Quarter. Be sure to have a good time at this museum in Manchester.

13. The Museum of Wigan Life

Overview: The Museum of Wigan Life, in the heart of Wigan, Greater Manchester, shows the history and culture of the area. It’s in a beautiful old building, built in 1878 as the Wigan Library. The museum is interesting and teaches people of all ages. It shows lots of different things, like local history, old industry, and how people in Wigan lived every day.

Highlights: The museum holds a wide range of photographs, maps, and documents showcasing Wigan’s development from its early days to the present. The social history collection includes everyday objects, clothing, and personal items that offer a glimpse into the lives of Wigan’s residents over the centuries, painting a vivid picture of community life, traditions, and social changes.

Special Exhibitions: The Museum of Wigan Life hosts a variety of temporary exhibitions that explore different aspects of Wigan’s history and culture. These exhibitions often include interactive elements, multimedia displays, and engaging narratives.

Visitor Experience: Visitors to the Museum of Wigan Life can expect well-designed exhibits, clear signage, a museum shop, and an on-site café.
